Introduction

Tourette syndrome is a childhood neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by multiple motor tics and at least 1 vocal tic.  Tics are sudden, brief, recurrent, nonrhythmic motor movements (eg, blinking, facial grimacing) and vocalizations (eg, grunting, throat clearing).  Tics can usually be suppressed temporarily and are often preceded by an irresistible urge followed by feelings of relief.  Symptoms must be persistent for >1 year, although they may fluctuate in intensity.

Epidemiology and risk factors

The estimated prevalence of Tourette syndrome is approximately 0.5%.  It affects males more often than females (4:1 ratio).  The average age of onset is age 6, with the majority of patients experiencing symptoms by age 11.

Several factors may contribute to the risk of developing Tourette syndrome, including genetic predisposition (heritability ~75%) and certain environmental factors (eg, maternal tobacco use during pregnancy, preterm birth, advanced paternal age).

Clinical presentation

Tics are sudden, brief, recurrent, nonrhythmic motor movements and vocalizations that can be simple or complex:

  • Simple:  short duration, involve limited muscle group(s)
    • Motor:  eye blinking (common), throat clearing (common), nose twitching
    • Vocal:  grunting, coughing, throat clearing
  • Complex:  longer duration, involve multiple muscle groups, can be a combination of simple tics
    • Motor:  hopping, kicking, imitating another person's body movements
    • Vocal:  repeating another person's words/phrases, saying obscenities (minority of patients)

Symptoms occur multiple times a day, frequently in bouts.  Most tics are preceded by an urge or uncomfortable sensation (eg, itch, tension) and are followed by a sense of relief.  Tics are not considered to be voluntary; however, they may be suppressed for varying periods of time.

Onset of Tourette syndrome typically occurs before age 11, with most patients experiencing peak severity from age 10 to 12 and symptom reduction during adolescence/adulthood.  Over the course of the illness, tics can change in type, intensity, and frequency.  Tics tend to worsen during times of excitement, anxiety, and stress and improve during periods of calmness and sleep.

Comorbid psychiatric conditions are common and can include attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), oppositional defiant disorder (ODD), and autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

Diagnosis

For a diagnosis of Tourette syndrome, the following criteria must be met:

  • Multiple motor and â‰¥1 vocal tics have been present at some time during the illness, although not necessarily concurrently.
  • Tics have persisted for >1 year since onset but may fluctuate in frequency.
  • Onset is before age 18.
  • Symptoms are not associated with effects of substance use (eg, cocaine) or another medical condition (eg, Huntington disease).

Differential diagnosis

  • Hyperkinetic movement disorders
    • Myoclonus also consists of sudden, nonrhythmic movements; however, the movements are not suppressible nor preceded by an urge or uncomfortable sensation.
    • Stereotyped movements (eg, hand waving, rocking) also consist of repetitive movements that can be reduced with distraction; however, these movements are rhythmic, longer in duration (up to a few minutes), and not preceded by an urge or uncomfortable sensation.
  • Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) can include compulsions consisting of recurrent motor movements (eg, eye blinking) that also result in a sense of relief; however, compulsions tend to be driven by clear-cut obsessions (eg, contamination fears).  Tic disorders and OCD can co-occur, in which case both diagnoses are given.

Management

Treatment for Tourette syndrome is symptomatic and dependent on the severity of tics as well as the presence of comorbid psychiatric symptoms (ADHD, OCD).  For mild tics that do not impair daily functioning, treatment should focus on psychoeducation and monitoring of tics.  For patients with severe tics, treatment is as follows:

  • Habit reversal training is first-line treatment for Tourette syndrome and is a type of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) that consists of 2 components:
    • Tic awareness training:  learning to recognize and become aware of urges, signals, and sensations that precede the occurrence of a tic
    • Competing response training:  performing competing behavior (eg, taking a deep breath) when an urge is experienced in order to reduce tic frequency and intensity over time
  • Pharmacotherapy may be appropriate if psychotherapy is inaccessible or if symptoms are severe.
    • Alpha-adrenergic agonists (eg, guanfacine, clonidine):  used for less debilitating symptoms; relatively lower risk for significant adverse effects in children; can cause sedation and hypotension
    • Antidopaminergic drugs:  may be indicated for severe symptoms
      • Antipsychotics (eg, haloperidol, pimozide, aripiprazole) reduce tic severity but are associated with decreased tolerability (eg, weight gain, metabolic syndrome) and increased risk for movement-related adverse effects (eg, dystonia, tardive dyskinesia).
      • VMAT2 inhibitors (eg, tetrabenazine, valbenazine) deplete dopamine through inhibition of VMAT2 and are not associated with tardive dyskinesia or metabolic syndrome.

For comorbid conditions, the following treatments are recommended:

  • Comorbid ADHD:  behavioral interventions and initial pharmacotherapy with alpha-adrenergic agonists (eg, guanfacine, clonidine); if improvement is minimal, may switch to stimulants (eg, methylphenidate) with close monitoring for potential worsening of tics
  • Comorbid OCD:  CBT with or without a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI)

Comorbid mood and anxiety disorders are common and require screening and treatment.  Tourette syndrome is associated with an elevated suicide risk and requires screening for suicidal ideation, assessment of risk factors, and safety planning.

Prognosis

Degree of impairment from Tourette syndrome is highly variable; patients with mild symptoms may experience minimal or no impact on daily functioning.  Approximately one-third of patients will experience complete resolution of symptoms, another third of patients will have symptom improvement in adolescence and adulthood, and the remaining third will have lifelong tics.  Poor prognostic indicators include comorbid psychiatric conditions (ADHD, OCD) and a family history of Tourette syndreom and/or anxiety disorders.

Summary

Tourette syndrome (
